overview.short: Pseudomonas fluorescens is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-fermenting rod best known for fluorescent pigment production and environmental prevalence.
overview.clinical_context: Usually an environmental contaminant but can cause opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients or via contaminated fluids/devices.

species_markers.notes: Fluorescent pigment (pyoverdine) is common in P. fluorescens group; pyocyanin is typically absent.
Failure to grow at 42°C helps distinguish it from P. aeruginosa.
Often weaker/variable compared to P. aeruginosa which is commonly nitrate positive.

common_confusions.reason: Overlap in oxidase positivity and non-fermenter profile; differentiation often requires temperature/pigment and confirmatory ID.
Both may produce pigments, but P. fluorescens lacks pyocyanin and usually does not grow at 42°C.

when_to_question_identification: Growth at 42°C suggests P. aeruginosa rather than P. fluorescens.
Blue-green pigment (pyocyanin) argues against P. fluorescens.
Oxidase negativity is inconsistent with Pseudomonas.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Separates P. fluorescens from P. aeruginosa.
Supports pyoverdine detection and helps classify within fluorescent pseudomonads.
Recommended biochemical panel for non-fermenting Gram-negative rods.
Most reliable confirmation at species level.
